topic.title: Decentralized Wifi Concept
topic.body:
So basically the core function of the Decentralized Wifi concept is still the same as zeronet, but with a twist

The DWifi software can run on any device that contains 2 or more wifi antenna's and can broadcast a AP on one of them

How it would work is by having each user download and install the software which inits their system much like how zeronet does with a bitcoin ID as the users ID. 
One Antenna would broadcast a DWiFi AP and the other would listen for other DWiFi AP, identified by the ssid `DWiFi-<the devices public key>`

Upon connection they will send a data packet between each other of other DWiFi Users as a list. < iffy, think of it like an auth into the network to make it harder to spoof a DWiFi AP >

There can be the common network users where they inter connect, hell it could work via bluetooth as well as that allows more connections

but there will need to be NODES, DWiFi AP's that are connected to the normal internet,( 2 wifi + 1ethernet, or 3 wifi minimum) allowing a DWiFi to act as a central connection node, which DWiFi client software will perfer, this will contain a data packet of all users connected to it that would be a list of Content that users Serve. And can be cached


Now it does need work, but the concept is there and it would function ALOT like how zeronet works. but more localized as it would require users to be near each other. Hence the node boxes that talk to a Peer-list to identify other users on other nodes,

Nodes can be setup in places like Airports, Trainstations, Malls, schools. 
It is still partially centralized because you need a node or two to serve as the Internet Access point, but if enough people use it (per-say, everyone in the world) you could daisy chain an internet connection several miles, 

Or it could function on a smaller scale such as every house in the Neighborhood has a Node that talks to each other, and has a battery backup. (such as a raspberry pi?)

topic.title: How to setup Zeronet with a SSL-URL locally!
topic.body:
*please do note this*: the url `zero.net` is in use here because who ever actually owns the real `zero.net` domain has not done *anything* with it in years, and its been broken as well, not even showing any form of ads. so the domain is basically *fekkin useless*

Okay so this is a bit complicated but here is what I have for you!

Please note I used [[clearnet] portainer](https://portainer.io) control panel for all of this

You need docker installed on your *primary pc*, the one you will be using zeronet from.

Install [[clearnet] pihole](https://pi-hole.net) into a docker container, 
- be sure to *temporarily* forward container port 80 to host port 81,
- forward port `53` on both UDP and TCP, and `67` on UDP
- I suggest setting the `hostname` for the container to `pihole`
- On windows I suggest downloading and installing [[clearnet] Nirsoft's QuickSetDNS](https://www.nirsoft.net/utils/quick_set_dns.html) program and using that to set your DNS server to `127.0.0.1`

Install [[dockerhub] Caddy](https://registry.hub.docker.com/_/caddy) into a docker container, this one will take a few extra steps
- I suggest setting the `hostname` for the container to `caddy`
- Please do forward ports 80 and 443
1. Mount `container/config` to somewhere on your PC, I perfer either `/opt/docker/caddy` or `C:/.docker/caddy`,
2. Modify the start command to the folling
	- `'caddy' 'run' '--config' '/config/caddy.conf' '--adapter' 'caddyfile'`
	- You can use something other than caddy.conf but I reccomend it, 
3. On the Host, install this program [[github] minica](https://github.com/jsha/minica)
	1. once installed, navigate to where you mounted `container/config` on your host,
	2. `mkdir certs && minica --domains zero.net`
	3. This will do two things, 1, generate a CA Auth Certificate in this folder,
	4. Import `minica.pem` as a `Trusted Root Authority` in your PC,
		- on windows you can easily do this by renaming it to `minica.crt` and opening it, 
		- I am unaware the steps on linux
4. I highly suggest this config for your `caddy.conf` but entirely up to you

```conf
# https://caddyserver.com/docs/caddyfile

import /config/certs/*/caddy.conf
```
 - This makes it so when you generate the ssl cert by using `minica --domains <domain>` you can just plop a `caddy.conf` in the cert folder,

5. Now, in `/config/certs/zero.net/caddy.conf` fill it with this, 
```conf
zero.net {
	tls /config/certs/zero.net/cert.pem /config/certs/zero.net/key.pem
	reverse_proxy zeronet:43110 {
		header_up Host "127.0.0.1"
		header_up Origin "127.0.0.1"
	}
}
```
if this breaks, comment out the header lines with `#`
6. Inside pi.hole, under `local DNS` add an entry for `zero.net` to point to `127.0.0.1`

7. ***[optional]*** Give `pi.hole` its own domain!
	- `minica --domains pi.hole`
	- add an DNS entry for `pi.hole` that points to `127.0.0.1`
	- `/config/certs/pi.hole/caddy.conf`
```
pi.hole {
	tls /config/certs/pi.hole/cert.pem /config/certs/pi.hole/key.pem
	reverse_proxy pihole:80
}
```

Now Install the zeronet docker container `nofish/zeronet:latest`,
- Do not forward the `43110` port
- I suggest mounting `container/root/data` to somewhere on your PC,
- inorder for the previous config to even work, you need to set the hostname of this container to `zeronet` or modify the previous config so that `zeronet` is replaced with the containers hostname
- now this is important, pi-hole will have made a new network, or atleast it should, if not, make a bridged network in docker.
- Assign all three containers, pi-hole, caddy, and zeronet to this shared network, 
- set `--ui_ip "*" --ui_host "*"`
And that should be all!

topic.title: Thoughts on possible zeromail clearnet relay?
topic.body:
So. I had a thought, no idea of how to code any of this but it would basically work like this
you can send mail from your zeromail address, to a clearnet email like so

Sending mail
```
to: mailrelay@zeroid.bit
topic: {target@gmail.com} your actual topic title
message: Whatever you like
```

Recieving mail
```
from: mailrelay@zeroid.bit
topic: {sender@gmail.com} the actual topic
message: Whatever they sent, 
```


Sending mail to relay
two proposed variations
```
{Varient 1}
{most compatible with current clearnet systems, but more likely to recieve spam and junk mail}
to: zeroid@zeromail.tld
topic: your actual topic
message:  Whatever you like

{Varient 2}
{program would be listening to an email address}
to: zeromail@gmail.com
topic: {merithtk@zeroid.bit} Your actual Topic
message: Whatever you like
```

Recieving Mail from relay
two proposed variations, Varient 1 and 2 from Sending respectively
```
{v1, again, most compatible but potential spam from clearnet services}
from: zeroid@zeromail.tld
topic: their actual topic
message: their actual message

{v2}
from: zeromail@gmail.com
topic: {merith.tk@zeroid.bit} Their Actual Topic
message: their actual message
```

Replies from zeromail would not work unfortunately as the relay would not log the emails sent, the only exception would be emails with HTML embedded, or emails with files attached, 

the `{example@zeroid.bit/gmail.com}` can be located anywhere in the topic, and will be parsed via regex to be valid, if it is not a valid email or zeroid, it will automatically reply 


Should an email come through with an attachment, or is an HTML email, the program would automatically spin a page up akin to zeroup, however the file would be encrypted and can only be decrypted when the decryption key is requested from the relay like so
```
to: mailrelay@zeroid.bit
topic: <encrypted file md5 hash>
message: decryption key
```

And because it recieves an zmail signed by your zeroid, it knows it is safe to send you the decryption key like so
```
from: mailrelay@zeroid.bit
topic: decryptionkey: <encrypted file md5>
message:
<decryption key>
<small blurb on how to decrypt the file on different systems, Linux, Mac, Windows>
```

Should a file be accessible through a link rather than requiring a download, it will be listed like so at the very bottom of the recieved clearnet email
```
{]Attachments[}
https://example.com/attachment.png
https://example.com/attachment.pdf
```

1594775906_1ufDwJisEDriKQxYJSz2HuUhgqAG1.body:
the hardest part, will be a consistant data directory, what you would probably really want, is a central service app that runs the zeronet service, but the apps can contain a bootstrap of their site so that downloading/updating is faster, 
```
zeronet.app
    Runs Zeronet
    Stores ZeroNet sites at /sdcard/Zeronet (on android)

zerozite.app
    Contains a "bootstrap" of the zite, which is then stored in /sdcard/zeronet/zite
    Checks if ZeroNet.app is running, if not, start it
    Once ZeroNet.app is running, open webveiw to zeronet.app/zite
```

as this would make more sense,  and make it easier to uninstall a site as zeronet.app can detect wether a zite was installed via app or browsing, if installed via app, and app nolonger exists, delete zite

to: zeromail@gmail.com <example>

sending from zeromail would function the same, 
```
to: clearmail@zeroid.bit
title: "user@gmail.com actual header here"
body: 
Your message
```

The clearnet receiver would see 
```
from: zeromail@gmail.com
title: sender@zeroid.bit The Title
body:
the body text
```
and viceversa for the zeronet receiver.

Replying would just auto reply to that email
